update.title: Py3 compat

content.raw: No. There are many cases throughout genomedata where `*args` and `**kwargs` were just used instead of passing paramaters. Sometimes there's an explicit replacement of `*args` throughout the pull request with actual arguments from argparse. The `**kwargs` has just been there for as long as I've known.
content.html: No. There are many cases throughout genomedata where *args and **kwargs were just used instead of passing paramaters. Sometimes there's an explicit replacement of *args throughout the pull request with actual arguments from argparse. The **kwargs has just been there for as long as I've known.

content.raw: @ericr86, do you know why this odd formulation of supplying a separate `kwargs` dict is used throughout genomedata command-line entry points? It seems unnecessary.
content.html: @ericr86, do you know why this odd formulation of supplying a separate kwargs dict is used throughout genomedata command-line entry points? It seems unnecessary.

content.raw:
With `optparse`, you feed in `args` (a `list`), and you get back `args` (a shorter `list`).

With `argparse`, you feed in a `list`, and you get back `args` (an `argparse.Namespace`).

Changing the type of a name in the middle of a function is not a good idea. Please change the `main()` signature in all these scripts to `main(argv=sys.argv[1:])` and use `argv` for the list and `args` for the Namespace.
content.html:
With optparse, you feed in args (a list), and you get back args (a shorter list).

With argparse, you feed in a list, and you get back args (an argparse.Namespace).

Changing the type of a name in the middle of a function is not a good idea. Please change the main() signature in all these scripts to main(argv=sys.argv[1:]) and use argv for the list and args for the Namespace.

content.raw:
In addition to the comments below:

From pyflakes:

```shell
$ pyflakes genomedata/*
genomedata/_close_data.py:67: local variable 'h5file' is assigned to but never used
genomedata/_info.py:17: 'die' imported but unused
genomedata/_open_data.py:53: undefined name 'options'
genomedata/_query.py:16: 'die' imported but unused
genomedata/_report.py:20: undefined name 'archive'
```

Done initial review

content.raw:
You should be able to `from genomedata import __version__` here. 

As long as the the developed module doesn't match the builtin modules (which "genomedata" doesn't) it will import the local modules first. 

Or even better use the new absolute imports to be explicit about it.
content.html:
You should be able to from genomedata import __version__ here.

As long as the the developed module doesn't match the builtin modules (which "genomedata" doesn't) it will import the local modules first.

Or even better use the new absolute imports to be explicit about it.

content.raw:
Although this follows this style used previously, it's probably best to follow PEP8 and put the imports at the top of the file. From the PEP8: 
> Imports are always put at the top of the file, just after any module comments and docstrings, and before module globals and constants.
content.html:
Although this follows this style used previously, it's probably best to follow PEP8 and put the imports at the top of the file. From the PEP8:

Imports are always put at the top of the file, just after any module comments and docstrings, and before module globals and constants.

update.description:
In response to issue #16.

Finally fixed `argparse` in `load_genomedata`. Added new command lines to docs.

See the closed pull request #10 for description.
update.title: Py3 compat

content.raw:
That hack doesn't actually take care of compiling the file. Currently we create a wrapper of `distutils.command.build_scripts` that does this for us. This probably needs to be changed.

I would be in favor of trying to get something through now that does easy changes like moving to `print_function` so that future code changes are done off that version.

Fixing the script building and actually getting this working on Python 3 rather than just closer to it should probably be a separate pull request as it will require substantive changes to `setup.py`.
content.html:
That hack doesn't actually take care of compiling the file. Currently we create a wrapper of distutils.command.build_scripts that does this for us. This probably needs to be changed.

I would be in favor of trying to get something through now that does easy changes like moving to print_function so that future code changes are done off that version.

Fixing the script building and actually getting this working on Python 3 rather than just closer to it should probably be a separate pull request as it will require substantive changes to setup.py.

content.raw:
I'll try to take a look at this tomorrow in more detail.

In the meantime I talked to Michael about this in person and we discussed that it's not necessary to get the `python3 setup.py install` part working. If it's too much trouble and if you want to submit the first steps towards python 3 compatibility that would be great as well.

I did a cursory check of the `future_builtins` imports and it looks like only a few of the builtins are used and they look compatible (for 3) with their current usage.

Also I looked into the issue about the binary distribution and it seems like a python 3 specific thing. The `scripts` portion of the setup function seems to be more strict. I've seen other packages use the `data_files` instead. I'm not 100% sure what the best solution here would be yet.
content.html:
I'll try to take a look at this tomorrow in more detail.

In the meantime I talked to Michael about this in person and we discussed that it's not necessary to get the python3 setup.py install part working. If it's too much trouble and if you want to submit the first steps towards python 3 compatibility that would be great as well.

I did a cursory check of the future_builtins imports and it looks like only a few of the builtins are used and they look compatible (for 3) with their current usage.

Also I looked into the issue about the binary distribution and it seems like a python 3 specific thing. The scripts portion of the setup function seems to be more strict. I've seen other packages use the data_files instead. I'm not 100% sure what the best solution here would be yet.
